bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, September 22, 1889

div1.p: Carter discusses the quarantine and his plans for the winter.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, September 22, 1889
div1.opener:
MARINE HOSPITAL SERVICE
1798 * U. S. * 1871
U. S. Marine-Hospital Service,
DISTRICT OF THE GULF,
Port of Chandeleur Island, Surgeon's Office,
Via Biloxi Miss
Septem 22, 1889.
Dear Ma:
div1.p:
The most important thing to me is the date. Quaran-
tine is passing & as it was unmercifully hot in September. I
hope that we may have a cold Oct. (especially the latter part) &
let up early. I am not so anxious for it to end as I
was last year because I am more used to it I suppose
& because I am further from shore & will be seldom
ashore even in the winter & I do hope the winter will
be better than last winter. Certainly Laura is in
much better health & the baby is bigger. Also we have a good
house & more room: the living in two rooms was not plea-
sant last winter.

The work of the summer is nearly done. I have
about three days work for the men, & then will
be ready to go into the winter. All the windows
have to be furnished with weights, but I hardly ex-
bected that to be done before the winter.
We were all on the island this morning
& there are many pretty places on it
when the wind blows hard enough to
keep the insects away & quite a
number of peculiar plants. These vines
I have found no where else & a wild pea that is very
nearly as large as our corn-field pea.

We had quite a ship wreck this week. Two men were on the
wrecked ship. Prince Lucien, ashore about 14 miles south of
us getting off her spars, & during a most tremendous wind
she turned over. Now “ashore” is about a mile or 3/4 of a
mile from the beach & in 22 feet of water & they were
washed off: we had a raft & on the cover of a hatch.
They came up Friday morning & we brought them
in & took care of them. One had had nothing to eat since
more Monday & one who washed 10 to 12 miles
lower down the island found a green water
melon which he ate. The children were profoundly in-
terested & looked on them as veritable heroes - although uninten-
tional ones.

Besides the men on the Sloop I will have probably but one
man ashore this winter - Barbara's husband. I had rather
have two but however it is not a matter of great impor-
tance. I

I presume that there will be pretty fair hunting here
this winter & although I have no gun I can borrow one I presume. There certainly were no
end of ducks - although very wild last winter when I used to come out here
I am certainly glad that the house is fixed & wish it could have been done
years ago,

Give my love to all at
home & in Ashland
div1.closer:
Your affec'ate son H. R. Carter There have been no more
Mosquitoes to speak of
since the bad nights
It is blowing a heavy storm
